Problem:
Consider a system governed by the partial differential equation \\( \\frac{\\partial u}{\\partial t} = Lu \\), where L is a linear differential operator. We are investigating the effect of applying a Fourier transform \\( \\hat{u}(k, t) = \\mathcal{F}[u(x,t)](k) \\) on the function u(x, t).

If the Fourier transform is applied to \\( u(x, 0) \\) and then the system is allowed to evolve under \\( \\frac{\\partial u}{\\partial t} = Lu \\) without further intervention, will the Fourier transformed state \\( \\hat{u}(k, T) \\) at time T be equivalent to if the Fourier transform was applied directly to \\( u(x, T) \\)?
Explanation: The Fourier transform of the solution of the evolution equation \\( \\frac{\\partial u}{\\partial t} = Lu \\) at any time T will be the same as applying the Fourier transform initially and then allowing it to evolve. This results from the linearity and the time-invariance properties of the Fourier transform in conjunction with the linear operator L.
